article.description: Jules Camara hit a jumper and Gerald Fitch made a pair of free throws in the final 53 seconds as Kentucky (No. 19 ESPN/USA Today, No. 18 AP) held off Tennessee 74-71 Wednesday night.
article.headline: This time, Wildcats hold off Vols in Knoxville
article.linkText: Kentucky survives thriller in Knoxville -- barely
article.story:
KNOXVILLE, Tenn. (AP) -- The hundreds of extra free throws Kentucky coach Tubby Smith has made his players shoot lately paid off.

Jules Camara hit a jumper and Gerald Fitch made a pair of free throws in the final 53 seconds as Kentucky  (No. 19 ESPN/USA Today, No. 18 AP) held off Tennessee 74-71 Wednesday night in the Southeastern Conference opener for both teams.

Smith hasn't been pleased that the Wildcats have been getting to the line so infrequently and then missing the few chances they do get. He now requires each player to shoot 100 foul shots at every practice instead of just having to make 10.

The custom probably won't stop now after Kentucky (10-3) shot
28-of-34 from the foul line for 82.4 percent, its best performance
since hitting nine of 10 against Virginia earlier this season.

``The key was getting to the free-throw line,'' Smith said. ``We attacked the basket better. We were more aggressive.''

Fitch was one of five Kentucky players who were perfect at the
foul line, making all eight of his attempts.
	   
``In order to build confidence you have to take a lot of shots. Shooting 100 free throws definitely gives you confidence,'' he said. ``I have to credit coach for my two free throws I made.''

The Volunteers (7-3, 0-1) trailed by five with 6:27 to go, but rallied to take a 71-70 lead with 1:21 left on C.J. Watson's breakaway layup. He was fouled on the play but missed the free throw.

The Wildcats, who lost by a basket in overtime at Tennessee last year, weren't about to repeat history.

Camara stepped back and made his jumper as Kentucky regained the lead at 72-71. The Wildcats' defense then kept Tennessee from getting another good look at the basket.

Vols coach Buzz Peterson called two timeouts in 20 seconds to set up a potential go-ahead basket, but Thaydeus Holden missed and a foul on Brandon Crump gave the ball back to Kentucky.

Ron Slay intentionally fouled Fitch, who made both foul shots
with 16.5 seconds remaining to seal it.

``It was a well-played game, but the bottom line is you can't put Kentucky at the free-throw line 34 times,'' Peterson said. ``We've been hitting our free throws, but we missed an awful lot of them down the stretch.''

Keith Bogans, who didn't start because he was late to a team meeting, finished with 20 points and nine rebounds for Kentucky. Fitch added 17 while Camara scored 12 points.

Slay reached his SEC-leading scoring average with 22 points, and Watson finished with 15. Jon Higgins, who fouled out with 7:38 to go, added 17 on 4-of-5 shooting from beyond the 3-point arc.

Kentucky turned the ball over 13 times and never really had control of the game despite outrebounding Tennessee 35-27.

In the closely called game, Tennessee got into foul trouble early. Three Volunteers had four fouls and another had three. Still, the Vols led by four at halftime and continued to lead midway through the second half.

After Slay made two free throws with 12:44 left, Bogans and Fitch made a pair each to give the Wildcats a 50-49 lead with 12:21 remaining. Slay rescued Tennessee with key baskets in the final 4:23.

Kentucky, which trailed by eight in the opening minutes, led temporarily before Tennessee closed the first half with a 31-29 lead.
